{{Infobox MLB player |name=Amos Otis |position=[[Center fielder]] |bats=Right |throws=Right |birth_date={{Birth date and age|1947|4|26}} |birth_place=[[Mobile, Alabama]] |debutdate=September 6 |debutyear=1967 |debutteam=New York Mets |finaldate=August 5 |finalyear=1984 |finalteam=Pittsburgh Pirates |stat1label=[[Batting average]] |stat1value=.277 |stat2label=[[Home run]]s |stat2value=193 |stat3label=[[Runs batted in]] |stat3value=1,007 |teams=<nowiki></nowiki> * [[New York Mets]] ({{By|1967}}, {{By|1969}}) * [[Kansas City Royals]] ({{By|1970}}â{{By|1983}}) * [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] ({{By|1984}}) |highlights=<nowiki></nowiki> * 5Ã [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star]] selection ([[1970 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1970]], [[1971 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1971]], [[1972 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1972]], [[1973 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1973]], [[1976 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1976]]) * 3Ã [[Gold Glove Award]] winner (1971, 1973, 1974) }} '''Amos Joseph Otis''' (born April 26, 1947 in [[Mobile, Alabama]]) is a former [[center fielder]] in [[Major League Baseball]] who played for the [[New York Mets]] (1967, 1969), [[Kansas City Royals]] (1970â1983) and [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] (1984). He batted and threw right-handed.
== Professional baseball career == Otis was initially drafted by the [[Boston Red Sox]] in 1965 as a [[shortstop]]. However, he put in some time in the outfield, [[third baseman|third base]], and [[first baseman|first base]] while playing in the minors. In November 1966, the Mets drafted him and jumped him all the way to Class AAA for 1967. He saw some time with the Mets late in the 1967 season, but spent 1968 in AAA again before making the major league roster for 1969.<ref name="Neyer">{{cite book |last=Neyer |first=Rob |authorlink=Rob Neyer |coauthors= |title=Rob Neyer's Big Book of Baseball Blunders |year=2006 |publisher=Fireside |location=New York City |isbn=0743284917 }}</ref> The Mets recognized his potential, so much so that when the Braves asked for Otis when trying to trade [[Joe Torre]], the Mets refused and Torre wound up going to the [[St. Louis Cardinals]] instead.
However, Otis immediately clashed with Mets manager [[Gil Hodges]], who tried to make him a third baseman. After only four games, Otis was sent back to the minors for a month. At the end of the season, Royals general manager [[Cedric Tallis]] sent seemingly hot third base prospect [[Joe Foy]] to the Mets, in exchange for the young Otis.<ref name="Neyer"/>
The deal turned out to be an epoch-making deal for the Royals, as well as one of the worst trades in Mets history. Foy was bogged by drug problems and was out of baseball by 1971. Meanwhile, the Royals immediately moved Otis to center field, and he became the club rock at that position for most of the 1970s. He made the American League all-star team each of his first four years with the team and won three Gold Gloves. His good speed worked well with the Royals' team philosophy of speed and defense.<ref name="Neyer"/> On September 7, 1971, he became the first player since 1927 to steal five bases in one game. He led the American League with 52 stolen bases that year.
On [[Brush Creek (Blue River)|September 18, 1977]], Otis helped out 8 youths who were stranded after a Royals game had been rained out when flooding had prevented the boys' parents picking them up. "If it was my kids," Otis said, "I would have wanted someone to do something for them, too." [2]
By the late 1970s and early 1980s, his fielding skills had declined somewhat, and he lost his center field job to [[Willie Wilson (baseball player)|Willie Wilson]]. He was still an important contributor, though, hitting .478 with 3 home runs and 7 runs batted in the [[1980 World Series]]. He spent a short time back in the [[National League]] with the Pittsburgh Pirates at the end of his career.
In a 17-season career, Otis posted a .277 [[batting average]], with 193 [[home run]]s and 1,007 [[run batted in|RBI]] in 1,998 [[games played|games]] while stealing 341 bases.
